response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms that the robot's end-effector (wrist and gripper) is positioned near the man's neck, which is roughly horizontal relative to the table surface. The robot arm is supported on a table with gravity acting vertically downward in the camera view. The neck is a soft tissue object covered with skin and muscle, allowing compliant and gentle manipulation. The robot grasp will be around the neck area, involving contact with soft tissue requiring moderate but careful force application to ensure comfort and safety. The environment includes a solid table surface underneath, restricting downward motions beyond the neck area. The robot wrist is close in orientation to the world axes but rotated such that the wrist +X is roughly forward (towards the man's head), +Y is roughly rightward (to the man’s right side), and +Z is roughly upward relative to the torso.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such:
- Wrist +X axis (red) points approximately forward in the world frame, aligned with direction into the workspace camera image (toward the man's head).
- Wrist +Y axis (green) points approximately rightward relative to the man/body in the image, roughly to the right of the workspace camera view.
- Wrist +Z axis (blue) points roughly upwards, approximately aligned with the vertical axis in the world.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to vertical world motion (upward when positive, downward when negative).
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object (neck tissue) must move mildly up and down (small oscillatory vertical motion) in a linear reciprocating manner to mimic massage pressure variation and release.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward/backward world motion towards/away from the head.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move gently forward and backward (oscillatory linear motion) along the axis of the neck to simulate gentle sliding and kneading massage motions.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to medial-lateral side-to-side motion relative to the neck.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move side to side with slight linear oscillations to replicate massage strokes across neck muscles.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object (neck and skin tissue) must be moved with combined small amplitude oscillatory linear motions of ± a few centimeters in the X, Y, and Z wrist axes synchronously, creating a three-dimensional kneading and stroking motion typical for a thorough neck massage.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck, we consider:
- Object Properties: The neck is soft tissue with an estimated small mass (~2 kg for the relevant section grasped), high compliance, moderate friction between skin and robot gripper (rubberized or silicone finger pads). The tissue is deformable but offers mild resistance to normal and tangential forces.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward, but the neck is held up by the man himself, not supported by the robot, so upward lifting force is minimal. The table below is firm but does not directly contact the neck during the task.
- The relevant object is soft tissue of the neck surface with mass ~2 kg and robot-object static friction coefficient estimated at 0.6 due to soft rubber grip pads.
- The surface of interaction is skin tissue with soft compliance and friction coefficient ~0.5 with human skin and robot pads.
- Contact Types: The robot uses a secure pinch-grasp on the neck with spread finger contact ensuring pressure distribution, avoiding sharp edges or point contact, maintaining stable but gentle grip.
- Motion Type: The robot performs cyclic linear sliding along X, Y, and Z axes combined with mild rotational torque about the Y-axis and Z-axis for twisting kneading motions.
- Contact Considerations: Normal force is maintained to keep grasp without slipping; tangential forces are modulated during sliding; torque about the wrist axes is applied to mimic manual massage twisting.
- Motion along axes: Combination of linear oscillatory motions along X, Y, Z wrist axes and mild angular oscillations about Y and Z wrist axes.
- Task duration: Massage session expected to last ~30 seconds to 1 minute for thoroughness.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates:
  - Mass of neck segment grasped: ~2 kg
  - Gravity: 9.81 m/s²
  - Friction coefficient gripper-tissue: 0.6
  - Friction coefficient tissue-skin: 0.5
  - Estimated maximum force applied in massage: ~15 N for comfort
- Relevant equations:
  - Required grasp force ≥ normal force to counteract tangential force / friction coefficient
  - Force needed to overcome static friction: F_friction = μ * N
- Relevant assumptions:
  - Tissue compliance allows small deformation; torque applied is small and within safe limits.
  - Robot’s control avoids large sudden forces to prevent injury.
- Computations:
  - Max lateral force ~10 N for sliding motions
  - Grasp normal force ~15-20 N sufficient to prevent slip (20 N * 0.6 = 12 N friction > 10 N sliding force)
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 2 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface:
  - To slide the neck tissue with 10 N force, grasp force must be at least 17 N approximately, which fits within the determined total grasping force range.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the required sliding motion along the neck and estimated soft tissue compliance, the robot must exert positive and negative oscillatory force along the X-axis with peak magnitude ~10 N.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the side to side stroking motion, the robot must exert positive and negative oscillatory force along the Y-axis with peak magnitude ~8 N.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the vertical kneading motion, the robot must exert positive and negative oscillatory force along the Z-axis with peak magnitude ~6 N.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon slight torsional twisting with forearm wrist rotation, the robot exerts clockwise and counterclockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude ~0.3 N-m in oscillatory motion.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon kneading rotation relative to the neck axis, the robot exerts clockwise and counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude ~0.5 N-m.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon twisting motion, the robot exerts clockwise and counterclockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude ~0.4 N-m.
Grasping force:  Estimated force range for safe, stable grasp is 15 to 25 N to ensure no slipping occurs without excessive pressure causing discomfort.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Soft human neck tissue, approx 2 kg mass segment, compliant skin and muscle, friction coefficient ~0.6 with robot rubber grip pads"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Combined small amplitude oscillatory linear sliding along X, Y, Z axes for kneading plus mild oscillatory torques about X, Y, Z axes for massage twisting"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.03, 0.02, 0.015]  # meters amplitude of oscillatory sliding motions approx 3 cm x, 2 cm y, 1.5 cm z
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [10, 8, 6, 0.3, 0.5, 0.4]  # N for forces, N-m for torques peak magnitudes
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 20  # N, moderate force to securely grasp without causing discomfort
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 45  # seconds typical massage duration
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
